The AI Policy Playbook: Navigating AI policy development through an African and Asian lens

This document, titled ‚ÄòThe AI Policy Playbook,‚Äô provides a framework for navigating the complexities of AI policy development, specifically focusing on insights and proposals derived from an African and Asian perspective. Developed in collaboration with FAIR Forward, GIZ (Deutsche Gesellschaft f√ºr Internationale Zusammenarbeit), and the Africa-Asia AI Policymaker Network, the playbook aims to offer practical guidance to policymakers. The core of the document centers around key findings related to AI policy challenges and potential solutions, shaped by the unique contexts of Africa and Asia. It‚Äôs a product of a concerted effort to address the specific needs and considerations of these regions within the broader global AI landscape. The project is supported by significant organizations including FAIR Forward, a program dedicated to promoting AI for all, and GIZ, a German international cooperation agency. The document highlights the importance of considering diverse perspectives when formulating AI policies, recognizing that solutions must be tailored to local circumstances. It emphasizes the need for collaborative approaches, bringing together stakeholders from across the Africa-Asia AI Policymaker Network. The authorship includes individuals from Carnegie Endowment for International Peace, alongside experts from GIZ and FAIR Forward. Production design and editing were handled by Design for development. Crucially, the document is released under an Attribution 4.0 International license (CC BY 4.0 DEED), requiring proper attribution and citation. The contact information for key individuals involved ‚Äì Deshni Govender (South Africa), Nadine Dammaschk, and Golo Rademacher ‚Äì are provided for further engagement. The document‚Äôs goal is to foster informed policy decisions and promote responsible AI development within the African and Asian contexts, acknowledging the significant role of international collaboration and knowledge sharing.

Key Concepts:

  • Development of AI policy through an African and Asian lens
  • Responsible AI
  • Attribution 4.0 International license
  • Open Access publication
  • Framework for AI governance
  • Multisectoral and multistakeholder approach to AI development
  • Leveraging AI for social and economic development
  • Defining legal and regulatory safeguards for AI
  • AI policy as a tool for control, promotion, advancement, or restriction of AI
  • Strategic definition of priorities for leveraging AI to benefit people and economies
